label: adjective
description: A word like [_big_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/big#English) or [_childish_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/childish#English) that usually serves to modify a [noun](#noun).

label: conjunction
description: A word used to join other words or phrases together into sentences.

label: determiner
description: A noun modifier that expresses the in-context reference or quantity of a noun or noun phrase. Determiners are often considered adjectives, but in fact are not quite the same; for example, in English, [_big_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/big#English) is an adjective, so “the big car” is grammatical while *“He saw big car” is not, but [_some_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/some#English) is a determiner, so *“the some car” is not grammatical while “He saw some car” is. In English, adjectives can _sometimes_ stand alone without a noun, while determiners nearly _always_ can (contrast *“He saw big” with “He saw some”), such that they are sometimes considered pronouns as well as adjectives.

label: interjection
description: An expression of emotion ("ouch!", "wow!") or any of several kinds of expression that functions as a replacement of a sentence ([prosentence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/prosentence)) or that are not syntactically connected to a sentence, including curses ("damn!"), greetings ("hey", "bye"), response particles ("okay", "oh!", "m-hm", "huh?"), and hesitation markers ("uh", "er", "um"), and perhaps profanities, discourse markers and fillers.

label: noun
description: A word that refers to a person (such as an [_actress_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/actress#English)), a place, a physical thing (such as [_wood_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wood#English)), or concept (such as [_beauty_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/beauty#English), [_joy_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/joy#English), or [_time_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/time#English)). See also [countable](#countable), [uncountable](#uncountable) and [plural](#plural).

label: preposition
description: A word, normally non-[inflecting](#inflection), that is typically employed to connect a following [noun](#noun) or [pronoun](#pronoun), in an [adjectival](#adjective) or [adverbial](#adverb) sense, with some other word. Examples of prepositions in English are _in_, _from_ and _during_. Note that some languages have [postpositions](#postposition) instead of prepositions; they function like prepositions but come _after_ the noun or pronoun being connected.

label: pronoun
description: A [part of speech](#part_of_speech) that acts as a substitute for a [noun](#noun) or [noun phrase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noun_phrase) and refers to a topic of the discussion. Pronouns can refer to a participant in the discussion and can be used instead of a person's name, such as with the pronouns [_I_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/I#English) and [_you_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/you#English). Other pronouns, such as [_he_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/he#English), [_she_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/she#English), and [_it_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/it#English), can be used to refer to other people or objects that have already been mentioned without repeating their names.

label: proper noun
description: A kind of [noun](#noun) that usually refers to a specific, unique thing, such as [_Earth_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Earth#English) and [_the Alps_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Alps#English), though one language's proper noun may translate to another language using a _common_ (not proper) noun. In English, proper nouns are usually capitalized, as are common nouns and adjectives derived from proper nouns. The same word may have both common-noun and proper-noun senses (such as [_German_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/German#English), which is both a proper noun denoting a certain language, and a common noun denoting a person from Germany), and most proper nouns can sometimes be used as common nouns – e.g. [_John_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/John#English) is a proper noun that is a first name, but can be used a common noun with plural [_Johns_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Johns#English) meaning "people named John".

label: toponym
description: A placename, or a word derived from one.

label: particle
description: A word that does not fall into the usual [part of speech](#part_of_speech) categories, but which modifies another word or the sentence as a whole. The English term [_like_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/like#Particle) is used as a particle in many dialects. Particles are more common in other Indo-European languages (e.g. German [_doch_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/doch#German), which marks a sentence as being surprising or rebutting a previous statement) and in East Asian languages (e.g. Japanese [_は_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E3%81%AF#Japanese), which marks the topic of a sentence). Many [clitics](#clitic) are particles.

label: participle
description: A form of a [verb](#verb) that may function as an [adjective](#adjective) or [noun](#noun). English has two types of participles: the [present](#present) participle and the [past](#past) participle. In other languages, also [future](#future), [perfect](#perfect), [future perfect](#future_perfect) participles.

label: perfect
description: The [aspect](#aspect) of a verb indicating that the action described is completed. In English, it consists of the verb _have_ + the past participle, e.g. _Tom has painted the fence_ or _Tom has taken medicine_. Depending on the tense of _have_ one can have present perfect, which are represented in the previous examples, or past perfect: _Tom had painted the fence_, _Tom had taken medicine_. _To have painted_ is a perfect infinitive. See also [_Imperfect_](#imperfect). Not to be confused with [_perfective_](#perfective).

label: verb
description: A word that usually serves to indicate an action, event, or state.

label: transitive verb
description: A verb which requires one or more objects.

label: intransitive verb
description: A verb that does not take a direct object.

label: multi-word expression
description: A group of words that functions as a single syntactic and semantic unit.
